title: Bland Gyro Plate
text: We visited the Olympia Ancient Ruins and the Olympia Museum on 2/27/2020. In early afternoon, the rains came. Many tourists had the same idea to get out of the rain by having lunch. Ambrosia Garden restaurant seems to be the closest eatery. With others going in, we followed. The restaurant was filling up quickly. We got a cramp table upstair in the loft area. We chose their gyro lunch plate special for around 10 euros each along with ten ounce Fanta soda & Sprite soda bottles for around 2.5 euros each. Gyro meat was laid on top of a bed of potato fried with a flat pita bread underneath both. Meat was on the dry side and the sauce bland. The side salad was nothing to rave about either. We were expecting tastier Greek food when eating in Greece. Service was hurried as if they want you to leave ASAP.

title: The Gates of Hercules in Ephesus
text: We visited the Ephesus ruins on 3/6/2020. On the pedestrian street is the Gates of Hercules. Reliefs of Hercules are carved on them on one side. The back side of the gate have not been found yet. Supposedly eighty percentage of the Ephesus ruins are still buried. The relief shows the strength of Hercules God thrusting his hand into the lion’s head. Amazing these are still standing for almost 2000 years.

title: The Temple of Hadrian in Ephesus
text: We visited the Ephesus ruins on 3/6/2020. One of the must stop on the main street is the Temple of Hadrian. This beautiful structure is well preserved and still has many of the original exquisite vine leaves and human figurines carvings on facades. The Medusa ornament is over the center arch. The inscriptions on the side columns in from of the temple remains empty as the original statues on them have not been found yet. Supposedly eighty percentage of the Ephesus ruins are still buried.

title: Ancient City of Ephesus, Turkey
text: We were extraordinarily delighted to have an opportunity to enjoy this site on 3/6/2020 before Covid-19 virus exploded worldwide and foreign tourism halted. A spectacular classical Greek ancient ruin city, only discovered in the mid 1800’s, is being excavated, preserved and restored even now. Over the eons, the city has been attacked, conquered and rebuilt by Romans. There was so much to see that you need a day there. Much of the ruins, estimated 80%, are still buried. Most impressive was the famed Library of Celsus built in 123 AD. Also don’t miss the amphitheater where St. Paul preached, the gates of Hercules and the stone relief of victory goddess Nike which inspired the Nike swoosh. Uncovered were paved streets, houses, plumbing, courtyards, baths and not to be missed “communal toilets.”

title: Panathenaic Stadium
text: This stadium has been rebuilt over existing stadium several times and is the only one built with marble. This was used as an Olympic venue in 2004 and also for the Olympic flame handover ceremony. Just a quick look is all you need here, not much more.

title: Old Medieval City of Rhodes
text: We were very fortunate to have an opportunity to enjoy this medieval city on 3/5/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and foreign tourism got shut down. We participated in a 30 minute walking tour and this wall city. The Guns of Navarone was filmed here. There are 219 streets inside. The streets are narrow and prevent those on the street from seeing the sun. So in ancient time, when invaders came, they get disorientated as to North-South-East-West. Also the street are lined with small cobble stones which prevent invaders using horses. Horses loose tractions on these cobble stones surface. Today, you have to be very careful because cars and motorcycles whizz through these narrow streets as this is still a working town. We saw the Castles of the Grandmaster, headquarter for the Knights of St. Johns, and the Great Hospital.

title: Acropolis of Lindos on the Island of Rhodes
text: We were immensely fortunate to have an opportunity to explore this acropolis on 3/5/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and foreign tourism halted. The massive temple area can be reach by foot after a steady steep climb to the top. On the way up, you have magnificent views of the Lindos town below with all the white color houses. This acropolis was built around 300 - 500 BC and is the second most visited Greece archeological site to the one in Delphi. It contains ruins from different cultures who built upon it over the millennia. You can see the ancient war ship that is carved into the rocks. When at the top, you'll see a spectacular view of the Bay of St. Paul and the turquoise Mediterranean.

title: Limassol Castle
text: We were hugely fortunate to have an opportunity to see this castle on 3/4/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and foreign tourism shut down. Castle was rebuilt on top of another with the walls strengthen to resist invaders. Also legend has that Richard the Lionheart on way to the Holy Land crowned his wife to be the Queen of England here. There were exhibits of Medieval potteries, tombstones and cannons. There was a neat display of an olive oil press on the castle grounds.

title: Ancient Theatre of Kourion, Limassol, Cyprus
text: We were extremely fortuitous to have an opportunity to enjoy this ruins on 3/4/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and foreign tourism shut down. We were able to visit ancient ruins in the hills of Kourion which were believe to be around 1000 BC, though there were evidence of humans inhabitants were there way back to 5000 BC. Our first stop was the complex of Eustolios where we saw rooms and courtyard of a bath establishment. We can still see mosaic murals on the floors. Then we proceeded over to the Kourion amphitheater which overlooked the Mediterranean. It is an impressive structure where gladiators once fought. It has been repaired somewhat over the millennia. There is a divot mark on the amphitheater floor where if you stand there, the acoustics are perfect. Just say something and your voice will echo throughout the entire amphitheater. Be sure to try this during your visit.

title: Kolossi Castle, Cyprus
text: We were highly lucky to have an opportunity to see this on 3/4/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and foreign tourism shut down. This castle is not one of architectural beauty but rather one designed for war. The structure offered excellent sight-line to detect oncoming enemies. Protectors can pour hot oil from the top onto perpetrators assaulting the entryway below. The crusading King of England. Richard the Lionheart married his fiancee at Kolossi Castle who later became the Queen of England.

title: Church of the Holy Sepulchre
text: We were remarkablely fortunate to have an opportunity to visit this church on 3/3/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and foreign tourism got halted. Another must see site to visit in Jeruselem. Once in a lifetime experience. Inside we saw and touched Stone of Anointing where Jesus’s body was washed and oiled after being removed from the Cross before being place in the burial cave nearby. We placed a piece of cloth on the Stone of Anointing to receive blessing that we can carry with us. Unfortunately we did not have time to wait in line to go into the burial cave. Also we were able to see the Rock of Calvary. The rocks were enclosed in an altar. It was said that when Jesus’s blood during the crucifixion fell onto the rocks, the rocks broke into pieces. Outside we saw the Immovable Ladder up against the right window in the courtyard.

title: Western Wall in Jerusalem
text: We were exceptionally fortunate to have an opportunity to tour this site on 3/3/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and foreign tourism got shut down. The Western Wall also known as Wailing Wall is an ancient limestone retaining wall built to fill a hill in order to support temple on top. This is consider holiest place for Jewish faithful to pray. The area is an expansive plaza. As you approach the wall, it is divided into 2 sections. Left side for men and right side for women. You may insert your written prays on paper into the wall, then pray. The women side was much more crowded than the men side. Harder to find an opening to access-touch the wall on the women side. A solemn place to visit.

title: Chapel of Saint Catherine
text: We were extremely lucky to have an opportunity to see this church on 3/3/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. This Roman Catholic Church is adjacent to the Church of Nativity in Bethlehem. It is built at the site where St Catherine was martyred. This is where the midnight Mass is beamed from Bethlehem to television viewers worldwide on Christmas Eve. Very peaceful church.

title: Church of Nativity, Bethlehem
text: We were exceedingly fortunate to have an opportunity to visit this site on 3/3/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. We have the opportunity to go into the Church of Nativity, the grotto where Jesus was born and the manger nearby. We heard the next day after our visit, Israel closed down for foreign tourists because of Covid-19. The church, originally built around 300 AD, is now owned by three churches; Greek Orthodox, Armenian Apostolic, and Roman Catholic. Greek Orthodox owned most of it as seen with the furnishings and embellishments. Just to be in there and be able to touch the spot where Jesus was born was a profound experience.

title: Egyptian Museum of Cairo
text: We were immensely lucky to have an opportunity to visit this museum on 3/2/2020 right before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. This review is for the Museum of Egyptian Antiquities in Cairo because the new Cairo museum is still under construction. You can take photos inside with cellphones even though the posted signs says no photos. If you have a regular camera though, you have a buy a ticket ($4 USD) in order to take photos with it inside the museum. The famed Tutankhamun gold masks and his associated tomb artifacts are kept in a separate room and has a no photo policy in there. There was a guard inside there to enforce the no photo policy. For antiquities aficionado who are passionate, you will probably need a week to marvel at the countless objects. The quantities of objects were amazing. Stacks of so many artifacts that they can easily fill 2 museums.

title: Pyramids & Sphinx of Giza
text: We were extraordinarily fortunate to have an opportunity to visit this site on 3/2/2020 right before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. We had to privilege to see one of the last remaining Seven Wonders of the Ancient World that is still standing, the Great Pyramid of Giza in Egypt along with the other two nearby. When you walk up to it, you have to be awed for the human labor needed to erect this massive pyramid. We also visited the other two adjacent pyramids too. We elected not to go inside the one pyramid that was allowed entrance, ($8 USD - a separate ticket). We also went over to see the Great Sphinx of Giza close by. Unlike the pyramids where you can touch them, visitors cannot go up close to the Sphinx. On your way there you pass by the mummification temple. We were in Egypt in early March. The weather there in the Sahara Desert wasn’t hot at all. Now for the negative. You will encounter many super aggressive vendors-peddlers. They just don’t take no for answer. Whether they want to sell you something, put something “free” on you, stand by you for a photo, they will reach for your camera or cellphone from you to take photographs, they says they will tell you how to take best photos, they will sell you a camel ride … they won’t take no for answer. Understandably because they are impoverished, they need your money. Nonetheless still very annoying and they can become obnoxious when you ignore them. If you want to ride a camel, be sure to negotiate the price ahead of time, and only pay after you get off the camel. Have your tour guide, if you have one, negotiate the price for you beforehand so as not to get ripped off.

title: Olympia Archaeological Museum
text: We were extremely fortuitous to have an opportunity to visit this museum on 2/27/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. The museum is a ten minute walk from the Olympia ancient ruins. The museum contains one of the finest collections of pediments and sculptures. They also displayed bottles, vases, and figurine carvings. Quite fascinating were the collections of bronze griffins and bronze battle helmets. This should be one of the stops for ancient Greece sightseeing.

title: Tavern Kalokerinos Athens Greece
text: We went here with high expectations for a delicious ethnic dinner and entertainment on 2/28/2020. We were sorely disappointed. The seatings were so cramp. The chair seats were so shallow that half of my thighs weren’t supported. The food was minimal and unremarkable. The entertainment was mediocre. For $66 US dollars per person, it was a complete let down.

title: Delphi Archaeological Museum
text: We were extremely fortunate to have an opportunity to visit this museum on 2/28/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. The Delphi Museum is located at the entrance of the Delphi archaeological ruins. This museum houses the famous Charioteer of Delphi bronze statue and consider to be one of the most important works of ancient Greece. There are other massive statues displayed throughout. Representative artifacts from the Classical, Hellenistic and Roman eras filled the museum. The museum is not that large but collections were well displayed. Toilets are located at the front of the museum.

title: Delphi Greece Ruins
text: We were immensely lucky to have an opportunity to enjoy Delphi archaeological ruins on 2/28/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. This huge expansive site has been dated back to 4000 BC. The archaeological ruins of Delphi displayed the well preserved Treasury of the Athenians. Excavation found sanctuaries dedicated to Apollo and Athena. There were many other remains e.g. theater, public places, and temples. Climb toward the top to see the stadium where athletic competitions were held. Lots of impressive artistic history scattered throughout here to look at.

title: Comfortable Amalia Hotel in Delphi
text: We stayed at the Amalia Hotel in Delphi on 2/27/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. The public space has panoramic views of the mountains. Our room had an extra bed. We overlooked an empty pool when we were there. They had light colored furnitures similar to most Greece hotels we encountered. Standard small flat-screen TV and Wi-Fi in the room. We ate both dinner and breakfast there. Good food and service.

title: Ancient Ruins of Olympia
text: We were terrifically fortunate to have an opportunity to enjoy this site on 2/27/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. The birthplace of the Olympic Games began here in 776 BC. We saw fallen stones and columns everywhere. There were mixtures of Hellenistic, Roman and Byzantine structures. The remains of Temple of Zeus still stood proud though many massive columns have fallen. The entrance to the stadium is an archway where the roof have eroded away over time. The stadium is sloped down to open field and does not have any stands or seats. In ancient time, both competitors and fans were naked. The Olympic flame is still generated here for each of the modern games today. That location was not much to look but the we can see areas where the rocks were charred.

title: Comfortable Arty Grand Hotel
text: The Arty Grand Hotel is located on top of a hill overlooking Olympia. We fortunately stayed here on 2/26/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. Our room was comfortably furnished and has a step down sitting area. There was a flat-screen TV, desk, mini-refrig and free Wi-Fi. Taking a shower was extremely difficult as there was no place to mount the shower head high. Also there was no shower curtain. The floor got really wet. We ate breakfast buffet and dinner at the hotel. We did not use any of the amentities. We experienced wonderful service throughout. A jewelry gift shop was located in the lobby. You can use Arty Grand Hotel as staging area to explore the nearby Olympia archaeological ruins.

title: Mycenae Archaeological Museum
text: We were highly fortunate to have an opportunity to enjoy this museum on 2/26/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. This little museum is located at the base of the ancient ruins. Toilets are located here and should be used before heading up to explore the ruins as there are none up there. The museum has a small number of important artifacts highlighting life of the Mycenaean to browse through. Most of the spectacular artifacts excavated at Mycenae have been moved to the National Archaeological Museum of Athens. Replica of the gold mask was on display here.

title: The Treasury of Atreus
text: We were awfully lucky to have an opportunity to visit this site on 2/26/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. Also known as the Tomb of Agamemnon, this is an impressive structure. Contents were pillaged centuries ago. Shepards have used it as shelter. The smoke from their fires stained the masonry. Nonetheless it was a marvel of ancient engineering as each stone was perfectly cut and fit in place as they inclined toward the apex. There was also a massive stone located across the top of the door frame which leave one to wonder how the ancients did it.

title: Archaeological Site of Mycenae
text: We were extremely fortuitous to have an opportunity to enjoy this site on 2/26/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. This was an important settlement during the Bronze Age. The grave circle at the base was were the famous gold death-masks and other gold artifacts were found. These are now kept at the National Archeological Museum of Athens. Remains of the defensive walls could still be seen. The Lion Gate supported by a massive stone block is recognized as the earliest known monumental structure of Europe and something to behold. An uphill hike to the Mycenaean Acropolis yielded wonderful vistas below.

title: A Quick Stop Unless You Want to Jump Off
text: We were very fortunate to have an opportunity to enjoy this site on 2/26/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. Humans dug the Corinth Canal to improve commerce by linking Ionian Sea to the Aegean Sea. This was dreamed up & digging began in ancient time but was only completed in 19th century. Location is around 1 hour from Athens. It was a stop to appreciate human labor. Marveling at it for a short time was enough unless you want to jump. Bungy jumping off the bridge is available though it was closed on the day of our visit.

title: Marina’s FARMA Meat House
text: We ate at Marina’s FARMA Meat House on 3/7/2020. It is located inside the FLISVOS Marina. Wine was very good. Dual musicians played Greece music while we dined. As for the food, my fresh catch of the day choice was tasty and aromatic. The atmosphere was nice though a bit loud inside. The view through the floor to ceiling windows overlooking the yachts in the marina was wonderful. Service was quick and efficient. Short stroll outside restaurant after dinner, we saw schools of fish attracted to the pier lights..

title: Changing of the Guards, Athens, Greece
text: We were quite lucky to have an opportunity to witness this activity on 3/7/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. We were lucky to observe changing of the guards at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldiers in front of the Hellenic Parliament in Athens Greece. They do this change hourly on the hour at Syntagma Square. Greek soldiers are dressed in interesting historical uniforms and the head of their shoes have red pompoms. Their movements are slow, smooth and deliberate during the ceremony. Takes approximately 15 minutes to see the entire process.

title: Acropolis of Athens
text: We were awfully fortunate to have an opportunity to enjoy this site on 3/7/2020 before Covid-19 virus contagion exploded worldwide and tourism got shut down. We visited Athens’ Acropolis in the morning. Sparse crowds allowing everyone going up and down the hill easily. Do be careful of the slippery marble surface walkway. The Parthenon is undergoing continuing renovations. Temple of Athena stood at the north side of the hill. The statues at the porch of Temple Erechtheum looked amazing. Views of Athens are spectacular as expected. This ancient ruins is famous but there are other ruins just as wonderful or even superior in Greece to visit.

title: Zafolia Hotel
text: In late February 2020, we stayed several nights at this centrally located hotel which was around 30 minutes from Athens International Airport. The staff was professional but not too efficient perhaps due to our language barrier. Lobby was neat and comfortable. Our daily buffet breakfast offered a variety of local and western choices was excellent. Our room faced the central street. It was very hot inside the room and it couldn’t be cooled down except opening the window. The street noise emanating below was unbearable when the window was opened. We received 1 bottle of complementary water daily. Free Wi-Fi in room. We didn’t use any of the hotel’s amenities. There were restaurants within walking distance and a small supermarket across the street. Hotel was around a 30-45 minutes walk to National Archaeological Museum, though a taxi would have taken 10 minutes. I would rate this hotel 3.5 Stars.

title: Wyndham Hotel-Resort at National Harbor
text: We had a nice stay at this hotel. Accommodations were comfortable. Service from the hotel staff was exemplary. The hotel has concierge service, computer room, game room, rec room, gym, & pool. Interior style seems to be mid-century modern. For a hotel that’s less than a decade old, the furnishings appear well worn around the edges. Declined discount offers associated with their timeshare presentation. There were no hotel shuttle service to Reagan International (closest airport), Washington DC, nearby MGM Casino & Tanger Shopping Outlet, or to buy groceries. No onsite restaurant either. CVS Pharmacy is on the same block as the hotel. Variety of restaurants, riverside attractions, and the Gaylord Convention Center were all within walking distance. Unless you have a car, consider taking ride share to visit DC because there weren’t any easy access to public transit or Metro rail. Ride share travel times to or from DC ranged around 20 to 40 minutes depending on traffic. Some Wyndham hotels put out cookies, tea, and coffee in the afternoon daily for guests returning from excursions. However this one does not.

title: Is Nat’l Harbor a good homebase to stay for DC visit?
text: National Harbor has the 2,000 rooms Gaylord National Resort & Convention Center. This clean compact area has limited restaurants, hotels and shops. Entertainment options include MGM casino, a large ferris wheel aka Capital Wheel, and a replica of Air Force One. There are some statues around to take photos. If you don’t have a car, you are pretty much trapped. This area offers no convenient ways to access the Metro. It’s possible but would take an inordinate amount of time to go to DC via Metro. To go to DC for sightseeing, it is best to take a Rideshare or Taxi. Of course, cost adds up. However you’ll be saving money on a car rental and daily National Harbor parking fees. Tanger Shopping Outlet is a mile away.

title: Definitely not Vegas
text:
We were in Las Vegas just two weeks ago. So this is hardly a fair comparison to the overboard decors of Las Vegas casinos and hotels. MGM casino has the usual games of chances. It good they have designated smoking areas. There are limited number of shops inside the hotel and few food choices at the food court. They did a
nice job with festive holiday decorations to fill the voluminous atrium.

title: Value Meal
text: Average sandwiches, but great salads. This restaurant offers good value if you don’t want to spend too much for a meal. Good for to-go or eat-in.

title: Not recommended
text: We went in for lunch because they displayed positive reviews of their restaurant outside. The place is a hole in the wall. We have eaten Chinese food around the globe. Their food is no good. Mixed vegetables were over cooked. Soy sauce chicken was bland. Roast pork was dry and tough. Redeeming was their average noodles. However the worst part of all is the food was lukewarm. The staff is in a hurry to get you in and out.

title: A bit slow
text: We only used and rode the red National Mall Route Circulator bus to get around the museums and monuments in the mall and basin area. The buses come around pretty regularly, approximately every 10 minutes. Cost is $1 per ride per adult. Because of high volume of vehicles in this area, traffic was brutal. Takes a long time to get from one stop to another.

title: Humongous acreage
text: On this trip over the course of several days, we walked the entire mall from the Capitol to the Lincoln Memorial. There are so many significant museums, galleries and monuments to see. Be ready to walk a lot. When tired of walking, take the National Mall Route Circulator bus. $1 per ride, comes around every 10 minutes.

title: Tranquility
text: Though not cherry bloom season, our crisp fall weather visit was nonetheless memorable. No crowds. So peaceful. Just walk around and enjoy the tranquility. Stumbled into the area where the first cherry trees were planted in 1912. The Jefferson Memorial across the basin is undergoing renovation.

title: Awe Inspiring
text: National Gallery of Art visit was just amazing. The gallery is ginormous. There are so many priceless paintings from famous artists you’ve read about in history; Monet, Van Gogh, Cezanne, and more. Modern 20 century artists’ stunning paintings were on displayed as well. Another sections was devoted to statues and cravings. Docent led art appreciation tours could be observed.

title: Self Guided Tour of Famous Documents
text: You have to go through security check to enter the National Archives. The museum entrance is to the left of the lower steps around the corner. Here is where you can view the original Declaration of Independence, Bill of Rights, the Constitution, and the Magna Carter. There are countless displays of other US historical documents. The are multiple exhibits about equality and freedom to ponder. Be ready for noisy student groups doing their civics class visits. No photos or videos permitted.

title: An under visited treasure
text: Our Renwick Gallery visit here was a delightful unexpected treat. Seems not as well known as other attractions in the area. This is an arts and crafts museum. Some artists’ exhibits were whimsical while others were technically simply amazing. For those who are makers, you can really appreciate the craftsmanship and visions that went into their works.

title: Bureau of Engraving and Printing Tour
text: Supposedly the FBI tour and this tour are two of the most requested tours through your state representatives. Unfortunately our scheduled approved Engraving & Printing tour conflicted with our approved White House tour on the same day. We were told limited tour ticketed are distributed daily in the morning. We went the next day and found out no tickets are needed from November to April. While waiting for the guided tour to start, you can peruse historic US money on display. There is even a $100,000 bill. No photos or videos are permitted to be taken during the tour of how US money is printed. There are cameras everywhere monitoring for infractions. We saw the printing press, the guillotine chopper and batch banding machines in action. This rather short tour is free. You can buy sheets of uncut US Bills in various denominations to take home as souvenirs.

title: A Most Impressive Museum
text: National Museum of Natural History is a must visit museum while in DC. Their exhibits are spectacular. So much informative placards to read through and audio & visual presentations to participate in. You can spend several days browsing and still wouldn’t be enough time to see everything. The National Gem Gallery has the Hope Diamond on display. An awesome museum and it’s free. But be ready for lots of noisy student groups in the museum daily.
place: Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History

title: Beautiful Library with Lots of History
text: This historic building holds the largest library collection online or in person. The copy right office is also in here. The grand architecture is stunningly elegant and beautiful. The reading rooms are partitioned off. You can do research online and in person. We didn’t want to sign up for a library card but you can get one. This attraction is free admission .

title: Touring the White House
text: There are no tickets distributed for the White House. Tickets are requested through your local state’s Congressmen or Senators offices six months in advance. Their office will submit your request. You will receive a link couple months before your visit dates. You will have to complete personal info online right away. The Secret Service will do background checks and notify your Congressman or Senator whether you will get a ticket. We got notified and received our tickets just one week in advance of arrival. The protocol for admission and touring are strictly enforced by the Secret Service. Your tour is led by a Secret Service agent who provides history information about former presidents, past events that happened in the WH, various paintings and furnishings. Only a few rooms were made available to be viewed. Tour lasted around 45 minutes. Pay attention to your official WH invitation if you receive one. Nothing hand carried is allowed in. We saw three people with purses/backpack removed from the waiting line and turned away. There is no place to check a bag. There are no public toilets in the White House either.

title: Statue Overlooks Scenic Basin
text: Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial was only completed within the last decade. It is located in the West Tidal Basin area. The humongous structure celebrates the man who heavily influenced the passage of the Civil Right Act through non-violence for which he also won a Nobel Peace Prize. It’s around a 15 minute walk from the Korean Veterans War Memorial. The site visit is free.

title: Stunning Expressive Statues
text: Korean Veterans War Memorial is located to the left (South) of the Lincoln Memorial. The statues of the soldiers are haunting. The Korean War still hasn’t officially ended, only armistice to end hostilities. The photo etchings into the wall are subtle and worth viewing from different angles.

title: A Monument Befitting Lincoln
text: A huge stone carving of Lincoln is housed in a Greek style temple in memory of his accomplishments in uniting the nation after the Civil War. There are restrooms to the left of the bottom steps. Just be aware, adjacent to the restrooms are more displays of Lincoln’s writings. We visited on a weekday morning where the crowd was surprisingly sparse and plenty of photo ops abound.

title: Vietnam Veterans War Memorial
text: Vietnam Veterans War Memorial located to the right (North) of the Lincoln Memorial. Remarkable are the totality of individuals who died in this war etched into the long marble wall. There were 2 stations containing a voluminous directory listing all the names on the wall. This directory may be used to find the person you are looking for.

title: World War II Memorial
text: A grand memorial structure built befitting the memories of the lost souls from that war. Walk around the structure and water features to appreciate the solemnity of sacrifices made. There was a park ranger there who can answer your questions. This peaceful remembrance site visit is free for all.

title: Washington Monument is Open
text: You obtain free timed tickets in the small building East of the monument. Don’t line up at the monument unless you have tickets. There are no tickets at the monument itself. The Park Rangers coordinate the line and how many people get in. The earliest are the 9 AM tickets Twelve visitors goes through security at a time. A elevator takes you to the 500 feet level. The monument is 555 feet 5 & 1/8 inches tall. The are only two tiny observation windows for each cardinal directions, North, South, East, and West. Depending on weather conditions, the views may be poor or spectacular. When done viewing, walk down one flight of stairs to review posters about the monument’s construction history. Then you get on the elevator to take you down. Hint: Stand in a spot by the opaque glass windows by the doors because the elevator slows down couple of times. The opaque windows becomes clear and you can see the masonry construction from the inside.

title: Tour of the United States Capitol
text: We had a fabulous private tour by planning ahead. Months before our travel to DC, we contacted our US Congressman to request a Capitol tour. We were granted a schedule tour led by members of Congressman’s Washington DC office staff. First we met at the Congressman’s office located across the street from the Capitol. They led us through an underground entrance into the Capitol. There were two staff members providing education about the buildings, the rooms, the history, the operations and the symbolisms. We asked as many questions as we wanted. They took photos of us upon request. This absolutely was the best way to tour if you can get one. At the end of our tour, we were given “good for the day” passes to attend hearings in both the Senate and the House.

title: History of Indians in the America’s
text: A decent museum to explore North and South America Indian’s history and ways of life. The visit is free. We witnessed a neat cultural demonstrations in the foyer. Even ate in their cafeteria, the touted Mitsitam Native Foods Cafe. The supposedly gourmet foods were lukewarm to cold, tiny portions and exorbitant prices. Didn’t taste good either.
place: National Museum of the American Indian

title: Humans & Flights
text: National Air & Space Museum is an must visit when exploring DC. It’s all there. Wright Brothers’s flying contraption to rockets to the space station and countless artifacts are on display. There are guided tours led by docents throughout the day or just explore on your own. Docent’s presentations on the difficult processes and the cramp environment of early space flights are just fascinating. Museum has interactive simulator if you can stomach it. Just like all museums in DC, expect to go through security screening. Smithsonian National Air & Space Museum completes annually with the Paris’s Louvre Museum for the number 1 spot for highest number of visitors yearly in the world. During our visit, an announcement was made that Air & Space is leading. And this museum has free admission.

title: Overall pleasant flights LAX to UIO, & LIM to LAX
text: Having read prior reviews regarding Copa Airlines services, I was anticipating the worst. Additionally flying to a foreign country and not speaking their language compounded my apprehension. I had concerns of not making the connection in Panama City due to a tight layover window. Walking swiftly over a long distance, I did made the Panama connection by 10 minutes. Overall I was pleasantly surprised by Copa Airlines’ on time departures & inflight services. The return to Los Angeles flights weren’t smooth. Experienced lots of turbulence from probably a nearby hurricane. The captain and flight crew got the plane back to LA in one piece.

title: LAX Marriott
text: To reduce stress of rushing to LAX in order to avoid missing our flights, we tried out their “Park & Stay” package at the Los Angeles Airport Marriott. Their package included 1 night lodging and valet cover parking up to 14 days for $300. They also offer the same package with 3 day parking and 7 day parking. This hotel was very nice. Considering the retail airport parking rates for cover parking for that duration, the dollar amount seemed fair. Hotel’s shuttle buses can drop you off at your terminal for departure and pick you up on return. You can text the hotel to have your car ready as soon as you fetch your luggages. The weren’t any shuttle buses for return pickup around 6 p.m. on a weeknight. Had to wait for more than 30 minutes before one showed up. Additional caveat about this package is there are no “in & out privileges” for your vehicle once you arrive with it. Therefore bring in take away dinners if you don’t like hotel’s restaurant food.

title: AC Hotel by Marriott Lima Miraflores
text: Location of this hotel is its greatest asset. AC Hotel by Marriott Lima Miraflores is a new contemporary and stylish hotel that just opened in 2019. Miraflores is one of the most desirable and expensive areas in Lima. Nearby cliffs that overlooked the Pacific and high end shopping mall Larcomar were quite walkable from the hotel. AC Hotel by Marriott Lima Miraflores has all the modern amenities you would expect. Free wi-fi and rainfall shower head. Staff was very helpful. However the hotel’s buffet breakfast with limited choices was rather mediocre. Additionally, water leaked out from shower stall flooding a wide area of tiles outside.
place: AC Hotel by Marriott Lima Miraflores

title: Asnapa Restaurant
text: This was a very nice open kitchen comfortable restaurant. Imaginative fusion food. Went there for dinner as member of tour group. We were all served with a beverage known as Nectar of the Inca. For starters, we had the Ceviche and Pumpkin soup. Main courses were Lima bean hummus topped with grilled fish and Peruvian style chicken casserole. For desert, we tried the Picarones which were crunchy fried donuts made from pumpkin & sweet potatoes. Efficient wait staff despite size of our group. All the foods were pretty good except for the rather bland grilled fish entree.

title: Lovers Park of Lima
text: The giant statuesque of a couple embracing is at the park center. There were a number of mosaics bench similar to the Gaudi’s design in Barcelona Spain. The view from this cliff side park is stunning. You can see a panoramic view of the Pacific Ocean coastline and surfers enjoying the water below
